instruction: Analyze this email impersonating the CEO, requesting a wire transfer for an urgent vendor payment.

input.subject: RE: Urgent Vendor Payment
input.body: Hello. Please transfer $25,000 to our new supplier account before noon. We risk a penalty if not done immediately.

output.description: Email impersonating the company's CEO, pressuring an employee to wire money to an unverified account.
indicators: External, non-corporate sender email domain
Demand for urgent wire transfer
Threat of penalty if not sent quickly
Spoofed CEO identity

instruction: Decide if this phone call, claiming to be the HR director, is a scam. The caller asks for employee payroll info.

input.scenario: Caller claims to need immediate access to payroll records due to a system error.

output.description: Fraudster impersonating HR director via phone, requesting sensitive payroll data with no formal verification.
indicators: Blocked caller ID
Urgent demand for payroll info
No established authentication method
Impersonation of HR leadership

instruction: Identify red flags in this email from 'Accounts Dept' about a supplier invoice with updated bank details.

input.subject: Updated Bank Details for Invoice #4512
input.body: Please note our new bank details for invoice #4512. Kindly make the payment ASAP to avoid delays.

output.description: Invoice scam email requesting payment to a newly provided bank account, impersonating a known supplier.
indicators: Domain mismatch or unknown domain
Unsolicited request to change bank details
Pressure to pay quickly
Likely compromised or spoofed vendor account

instruction: Examine this text message claiming to be from HR, asking for employee Social Security numbers. Classify it.

input.message_text: HR ALERT: We need your SSN immediately to finalize new benefits. Reply now.

output.description: Text message impersonating HR, requesting SSNs from employees without proper procedure.
indicators: Unsolicited request for SSN
No official HR contact method
Pressure to respond immediately via SMS
Attempt to gather sensitive personal data

instruction: Determine whether this email from the CFO about an urgent bill payment to an unknown vendor is legitimate.

input.subject: Urgent Bill Payment Needed - Invoice #X701
input.body: We must pay an outstanding invoice immediately. Transfer $10,000 to the attached account details.

output.description: BEC email impersonating CFO, demanding immediate payment for a suspicious invoice.
indicators: Urgent tone from CFO with unfamiliar domain
Vague references to invoice details
Pressure to bypass standard approval protocols
Potential BEC (Business Email Compromise)

instruction: Analyze this voicemail from an individual claiming to be an external HR consultant, requesting employee tax info.

input.message_content: This is the new HR consultant. I need the W-2 forms for all employees. Please call back with the data.

output.description: Unknown caller masquerading as HR consultant, aiming to obtain employee tax forms (W-2) for identity theft.
indicators: No official introduction or reference from real HR
Demand for bulk sensitive employee data
Caller ID unknown or restricted
Potential attempt to gather personal info on employees

instruction: Identify whether this email from 'Legal Department' about a past-due invoice is part of an invoice scam.

input.subject: Final Notice: Past-Due Invoice #8812
input.body: Your account is in arrears for invoice #8812. Pay immediately to avoid legal repercussions.

output.description: Phony collections threat, pressuring the recipient to pay a suspicious invoice or face alleged legal actions.
indicators: No official company domain or internal references
Threatening legal language for immediate payment
Lack of official invoice documentation or history
Likely fake invoice to intimidate quick payment

instruction: Determine if this LinkedIn message from 'HR Specialist' about verifying personal bank info is a scam.

input.message_content: We need to finalize your direct deposit. Please send your full bank account details here in chat.

output.description: Fake HR request on LinkedIn asking for sensitive financial info via chat, a strong sign of phishing.
indicators: Unsolicited request for direct deposit details
No secure portal or official HR system used
Likely impersonation or unauthorized approach
Attempts to gather personal banking info quickly

instruction: Evaluate this phone call claiming to be from the finance department, instructing a vendor payment change.

input.scenario: Caller demands the AP clerk update vendor bank details to a new account, effective immediately.

output.description: Call instructing an urgent vendor bank detail change, likely a BEC tactic to reroute payments.
indicators: Insistence on immediate banking update
No official request or email from recognized domain
Caller ID does not match known internal lines
High risk of payment diversion to a fraudulent account

instruction: Classify this email request from a CFO about purchasing gift cards as suspicious or valid.

input.subject: Gift Cards Needed for Client
input.body: Please buy $2,000 in Amazon gift cards and send me the codes ASAP for a client appreciation event.

output.description: Gift card scam impersonating CFO, requesting codes that can be instantly redeemed, a classic CEO/CFO fraud approach.
indicators: Unfamiliar domain extension (.info)
Unusual or urgent request for gift cards
No official procedure or PO for purchase
Frequent hallmark of BEC/CEO scams

instruction: Analyze this email about a 'management-level pay adjustment' from a suspicious HR domain. Scam or not?

input.subject: Management Pay Adjustment Notice
input.body: We have processed a raise for your position. Confirm your bank details to receive backpay.

output.description: Phishing email impersonating HR, luring employees with a fake pay raise to obtain financial credentials.
indicators: Unknown domain not matching official HR/Company domain
Promise of unexpected pay raise requiring account info
Likely leads to phishing form or direct data request
Tactic exploiting employee excitement about raises

instruction: Identify red flags in a text message telling an employee they must pay a 'uniform fee' via a provided link.

input.message_text: HR: Uniform fee is overdue. Pay $100 now at hxxp://hr-pay-fees[.]biz or face payroll deduction.

output.description: Threatening text claiming a uniform fee is overdue, directing to a suspicious payment site.
indicators: Unofficial, suspicious URL
Threat of payroll deduction if not paid promptly
No prior notice or official email about uniform fees
Likely a scam to capture payment info

instruction: Decide if this email about an 'overpaid invoice' from the AR department is legitimate or a scam tactic.

input.subject: Overpaid Invoice Refund - Immediate Attention
input.body: We have discovered an overpayment on your recent invoice. Fill out the attached form to receive a refund.

output.description: Scam email claiming an overpayment, prompting the target to fill out a form that likely harvests financial details.
indicators: Unknown AR department domain
Promises a refund with no supporting invoice detail
Likely malicious attachment or link
Overpayment/refund approach is a common BEC variation

instruction: Evaluate the authenticity of an in-person courier delivering a sealed envelope with an invoice and a new bank account.

input.scenario: Courier claims urgent invoice re-issue, instructing accounts payable to wire funds to the enclosed bank detail.

output.description: Physical scam attempt: unsolicited courier delivers a changed invoice with new bank info, urging immediate payment.
indicators: Unexpected invoice re-issue by hand delivery
Altered bank account details with no prior notice
High-pressure tactic for immediate wire
No official verification or contact from known vendor

instruction: Analyze this phone call from someone claiming to be the CEO, instructing urgent changes to employee direct deposit info.

input.scenario: Caller insists HR must move certain employees’ direct deposits to new accounts.

output.description: Impersonator calls HR, demanding immediate payroll changes to redirect employees’ pay to fraudulent accounts.
indicators: CEO impersonation with no prior internal request
Urgent demand to bypass standard procedures
Restricted caller ID preventing callback verification
Likely part of a payroll diversion scheme

instruction: Identify if an email from a supplier about a second invoice for an 'accidental undercharge' is a scam or real.

input.subject: IMPORTANT: Additional Invoice for Undercharge
input.body: We realized your last invoice was undercharged by $1,200. Please wire the balance to the updated account.

output.description: Fake additional invoice request from a suspicious domain, claiming an undercharge and demanding a wire transfer.
indicators: New domain that differs slightly from the real supplier site
Request to pay 'undercharge' with no breakdown or references
Demands an immediate wire transfer
Possibility of compromised or spoofed billing email

instruction: Determine if this text message from 'Company Rewards Team' about a bonus deposit is genuine or a phishing attempt.

input.message_text: Congrats! You’ve been awarded a $500 bonus. Update direct deposit details here: hxxp://secure-bonus[.]link

output.description: Smishing message promising a bonus deposit, linking to a dubious site to steal personal or banking details.
indicators: Unexpected bonus notification via generic SMS
URL not associated with internal HR or payroll systems
High incentive to quickly click and 'update' info
Likely personal data harvesting

instruction: Classify this email from a CFO about 'reimbursing an overpaid client' with no official invoice reference. Scam or not?

input.subject: URGENT: Overpayment Refund to Client
input.body: Please arrange an immediate refund of $8,000 to the client’s bank details attached. No time to lose!

output.description: BEC attempt impersonating CFO, instructing finance to send a large sum to an arbitrary account.
indicators: Sense of urgency with no invoice or client info provided
Suspicious domain that differs from the real corporate domain
Amount and request not confirmed through official channels
Likely fraudulent payout redirection

instruction: Review this chat message from a coworker’s Slack handle, asking you to pay a vendor immediately. Is it safe?

input.message_content: Hey, I'm in a meeting. Please pay vendor ACME Inc. $4,500 now. I'll explain later.

output.description: Compromised coworker Slack account directing an urgent vendor payment, typical BEC technique on internal messaging platforms.
indicators: Abrupt money request with no context or invoice detail
Uses Slack to circumvent normal accounting workflow
Claim of being in a meeting to avoid phone verification
Likely coworker’s account is hacked or spoofed

instruction: Decide if this email about updating 'employee medical benefits' is a legitimate HR notice or a phishing scam.

input.subject: Employee Benefits Renewal - Action Required
input.body: We need updated personal data, including SSN and date of birth, to process your new health plan.

output.description: Email impersonating HR benefits, seeking personal data through an unverified domain and lacking official disclaimers.
indicators: Sketchy domain not matching official HR contact
Direct request for sensitive personal info
No link to official internal portal
Likely identity theft or credential phishing

instruction: Check if this postal mail invoice from a new 'consultant' is legitimate or a fake invoice scam.

input.letter_content: Invoice #C-102: $650 for consultation. Pay by check to PO Box 123, or call to confirm details.

output.description: Paper invoice for unsolicited consulting services with vague descriptions, typical of a small business invoice scam.
indicators: Unrecognized consulting services or prior arrangement
Generic PO box for payment remittance
No itemized description or contact references
Likely tries to collect quick payment from unsuspecting recipients

instruction: Analyze whether this in-person request from someone claiming to be a new HR rep is suspect.

input.scenario: Individual arrives, says they need staff personal files immediately for an HR audit.

output.description: Person physically impersonating HR to access confidential staff records, lacking official ID or appointment.
indicators: No prior notice or official documentation
Refusal to show official company badge or ID
Demands immediate access to personal files
Possible attempt to steal sensitive data

instruction: Identify red flags in a phone call from 'Accounts Payable' requesting re-routing a large invoice to a new address.

input.scenario: Caller claims an updated address for mailing a check, insists on immediate redirection.

output.description: Caller impersonating AP, instructing to send a high-value check to a changed address, typical invoice redirection scam.
indicators: No official notice or email from known internal domain
Insistence on immediate check mailing changes
Caller ID not recognized or withheld
Could lead to checks being cashed by fraudsters

instruction: Evaluate this email from a 'new CFO' introducing themselves and asking for a list of employees with salaries.

input.subject: Meet the New CFO - Action Required
input.body: Send me the full list of employees and their current salaries for a budget review.

output.description: Phishing email claiming to be from a new CFO, seeking sensitive salary data, typical HR/finance infiltration attempt.
indicators: No internal announcement about a new CFO
Generic domain .me with no official references
Demands sensitive HR data without secure channel
Likely personal or corporate espionage tactic

instruction: Assess if this text message from 'HR Dept' urging to click a link to update personal info is a scam.

input.message_text: Important: Update your personal info for the new payroll system. hxxp://hr-payroll-update[.]host

output.description: Smishing attempt, linking to a suspicious domain for 'personal info updates,' impersonating HR.
indicators: Text from unknown short code or name (HR-ALERT)
URL with suspicious TLD (.host)
No prior email or official announcement about payroll changes
Likely data-harvesting scam

instruction: Determine if an email instructing immediate gift card purchases from the HR manager is legitimate or not.

input.subject: Quick Help Needed - Employee Recognition
input.body: We need $1,000 in Walmart gift cards to distribute as employee rewards. Please purchase and send codes ASAP.

output.description: BEC style request impersonating HR manager, pushing for gift card purchases with codes upfront.
indicators: Domain mismatch (company-urgent.work)
Unusual request for gift cards in large sum
Immediate demand for code sharing
Common gift card scam tactic

instruction: Classify this phone call from someone claiming to be an external auditing firm, requesting copies of all vendor invoices.

input.scenario: Caller claims the company is behind on an external audit and needs invoice records emailed to them immediately.

output.description: Fake auditor requesting large sets of financial documents, likely to glean data for further fraud or infiltration.
indicators: No prior engagement letter or known audit schedule
Pushes for immediate submission of sensitive financial info
No legitimate credentials or references shared
Likely disguised data collection attempt

instruction: Analyze this email from 'CEO Office' asking for employees’ personal phone numbers and addresses. Suspicious or real?

input.subject: Personal Contact Verification
input.body: We need to confirm direct lines for all employees. Please compile addresses and cell numbers and send them to me.

output.description: CEO impersonation targeting personal contact details for all employees, common BEC data-harvesting approach.
indicators: Unknown domain (corp-admin.info)
Request for extensive employee personal info without justification
Urgent or direct command from alleged CEO
Likely identity theft or spear-phishing preparation

instruction: Identify potential invoice fraud in this email referencing an unknown 'freelance consultancy' fee.

output.description: Fake freelance consultancy invoice with no prior contract or known project, pushing the recipient to pay quickly.
indicators: Unrecognized consultancy company or domain
PDF invoice for unrequested services
Likely tries to slip into AP as a routine invoice
Common tactic to defraud finance departments

instruction: Evaluate if a Slack message from 'HR_Bonuses' about uploading personal data to a Google Form is legitimate.

input.message_content: Upload your social security and banking details here for bonus eligibility: [Google Form link]

output.description: Unauthorized Slack user impersonating HR, using a Google Form to collect sensitive data under the guise of bonuses.
indicators: Generic account name 'HR_Bonuses' not matching official HR staff
Request for SSN and banking info via public Google Form
No internal HR system usage or official communication
Immediate red flag for phishing

instruction: Decide if this phone text about a 'backdated raise' from HR is credible or a social engineering scam.

input.message_text: HR Update: You have a backdated raise. Submit your direct deposit info here: hxxp://hr-raiseportal[.]org

output.description: Smishing claim of a surprise backdated raise, linking to an unverified portal to gather direct deposit credentials.
indicators: Highly unusual domain extension (.org) not affiliated with official HR
Unexpected raise notice without official letter or email
Encourages immediate deposit data submission
Likely bank account phishing attempt

instruction: Analyze this email claiming to be from 'Payroll Dept' about adjusting employees’ tax withholding. Malicious or not?

input.subject: RE: Employee Tax Withholding Adjustments
input.body: We noticed some irregularities. Send each employee’s SSN and pay rate so we can correct them.

output.description: Phishing email seeking SSNs and pay details under a false pretense of 'withholding adjustments.'
indicators: Strange domain (companytaxupdate.com)
No official steps or secure portal for data changes
Large-scale request for sensitive info
Likely identity theft approach

instruction: Check if this letter arrived by mail is legitimate: 'Final Overdue Payment' demanding immediate check to a P.O. Box.

input.letter_content: We represent your software supplier. Pay $1,850 now or we escalate to legal action. Remit to P.O. Box 567.

output.description: Paper letter claiming to be from a collections agency for a 'software supplier,' forcing a payment to a PO box with no details.
indicators: No official reference or invoice number provided
Generic name 'Collections & Recoveries Inc.'
PO Box only for payment, no phone or contact references
High-pressure legal threat to coerce payment

instruction: Identify if this Teams chat from 'Finance Head' about sending an urgent wire to cover a missed invoice is safe or not.

input.message_content: We missed an invoice payment. Wire $5,500 to the vendor's new account within the next hour.

output.description: Likely compromised Teams account or impersonation, instructing an immediate wire transfer under false urgency.
indicators: No official invoice or purchase order details
Unusual or urgent demand on a chat platform
No existing email chain or mention from actual finance policy
Common BEC style on internal collaboration tools

instruction: Analyze this call from 'Corporate HR' claiming a new 401(k) plan, asking for personal data. Suspicious or real?

input.scenario: Caller says they need personal details to enroll employees in a new 401(k) plan, including SSN, date of birth.

output.description: Cold call impersonating HR to gather personal data under the guise of setting up new 401(k) benefits.
indicators: Unverified phone number or identity
Immediate request for sensitive data over phone
No prior company-wide announcement or memo
Likely identity theft or benefits fraud

instruction: Determine if a text from 'CEO’s personal number' about an emergency vendor payment is legitimate.

input.message_text: I'm in a meeting, can't talk. Need you to send $2,000 to vendor X right now. Will explain later.

output.description: CEO impersonation via text, requesting an urgent payment with no official approval flow or context.
indicators: Unrecognized personal number for CEO
Urgent request bypassing normal process
No supporting invoice or purchase details
Telltale sign of BEC scenario

instruction: Review this Slack DM from 'HRCoordinator' about a new company health check, requiring personal data. Scam or not?

input.message_content: We’re implementing health screenings. Please fill out your SSN and address in this form: [Shortened URL]

output.description: Fake or compromised Slack account instructing employees to share SSN and address via a suspicious link.
indicators: Shortened URL with no official domain
Demands personal data with no official HR system mention
Generic role name 'HRCoordinator' not recognized
Likely data-harvesting attempt

instruction: Identify red flags in an email from 'vendor@updated-payee[.]com' referencing a changed invoice settlement process.

input.subject: RE: Revised Payment Instructions for Invoice #1001
input.body: Please disregard previous bank info and pay the outstanding amount to our new account details attached.

output.description: Vendor impersonation with a suspicious domain, urging an urgent switch in bank details to intercept payments.
indicators: Unfamiliar or newly created domain
Immediate request to change established bank instructions
Attachment likely containing fraudulent details
Common tactic in invoice redirection scams

instruction: Classify this phone call from someone claiming to be 'VP of Finance' demanding immediate invoice settlement to avoid penalties.

input.scenario: Caller says a vendor is threatening litigation unless paid today, instructs wire to a new account now.

output.description: Impersonation of a VP of Finance, using legal threats as leverage to push a same-day wire to an unknown account.
indicators: Sudden urgent threat of litigation with no official documentation
Redirect of funds to a 'new account'
Caller ID not recognized or mismatch with real corporate line
High-pressure BEC tactic

instruction: Check if an in-person approach by someone claiming to be an invoice collections officer is legitimate or a scam attempt.

input.scenario: Individual demands a check for an overdue invoice, providing only a personal ID and no official references.

output.description: Unverified person physically collecting a supposed overdue invoice payment, offering no formal company documentation.
indicators: No legitimate proof of official collections agency or assignment
Requests immediate check payment in-person
Only personal ID shown, no matching corporate credentials
Likely a con to gather quick, untraceable funds

instruction: Analyze an email from 'HR@employee-verification[.]team' urging employees to confirm personal addresses. Suspicious or valid?

input.subject: Employee Address Confirmation Needed
input.body: Click the link below to verify your home address and phone number for our updated records. Deadline: 24 hours.

output.description: Phishing attempt from an unofficial HR domain, requiring employees to 'verify' personal info on short notice.
indicators: Strange domain (employee-verification.team)
Tight 24-hour deadline to create urgency
Link likely leads to a data capture form
No mention of official company channels or login

instruction: Determine if a text from 'CEO' stating to buy gift cards for a corporate event is legitimate or fraudulent.

input.message_text: In a meeting right now, buy $1,500 in Apple gift cards for a conference raffle. Send pictures of codes ASAP.

output.description: CEO impersonation via SMS, typical gift card scam demanding immediate code sharing with no standard procedure.
indicators: Unknown phone number posing as CEO
Large gift card purchase with code distribution
Pressures immediate compliance (in a meeting)
Classic BEC-style gift card fraud

instruction: Review an internal chat from someone claiming to be 'Head of HR' on Microsoft Teams, requesting employees’ ID scans. Classify it.

input.message_content: Send me scanned copies of your driver’s license or passport to confirm your identity in our records.

output.description: High-risk request for scanned government IDs, likely from a compromised or fake HR account on Teams.
indicators: Unusual request for ID scans with no official policy
No secure upload or official HR forms
Could be used for identity theft or further hacking
Internal platform account possibly spoofed

instruction: Analyze an email from a newly hired CFO (allegedly) about pending vendor checks. Is it legitimate or a BEC scam?

input.subject: Pending Checks Must Be Reissued
input.body: I've reviewed the vendor checks. Please void the current ones and send new checks to the attached address.

output.description: New 'CFO' email redirecting vendor checks to a suspicious address, typical BEC infiltration method.
indicators: No official internal memo about CFO appointment
External domain .org not used by the real corporation
Instruction to void existing checks and mail new ones
Likely an attempt to intercept corporate funds

instruction: Identify red flags in this phone call from 'Internal Auditor' demanding immediate vendor statements to detect fraud.

input.scenario: Caller claims there’s suspected fraud, asks for all vendor bank statements, instructs to email to them directly.

output.description: Fake internal audit approach wanting full vendor bank statements, enabling future targeted payment diversion.
indicators: No official internal auditor name or known extension
Urgent request for sensitive financial docs
Asks for direct email vs. official shared drive or secure system
Likely BEC or vendor impersonation scheme

instruction: Determine if this email about new 'employee compliance training fees' from HR is malicious or genuine.

input.subject: Employee Training Fees - Immediate Payment

output.description: HR compliance fee scam instructing employees to pay an unexpected sum via an attachment or link.

Mandatory fee unusual for internal training
Attachment or link likely collects payment details
Urgent 48-hour timeline raises suspicion

instruction: Review whether an email from 'AccountsReceivable@finance-docs[.]info' about finalizing a partial invoice is safe or not.

input.subject: Partial Invoice #9023 - Final Amount Due
input.body: We must complete your partial payment. Please verify your bank details in the attached PDF form.

output.description: Unknown AR email domain, requesting bank verification via PDF, typical invoice scam to steal banking info.
indicators: Sender domain not recognized as official finance department
Attaches suspicious form for banking details
Claims partial payment with no prior communication
Likely leads to stolen financial credentials

instruction: Check if this text message from 'Head of Accounts' is malicious: demands an urgent vendor payment with a link.

input.message_text: We risk a late fee. Pay the vendor $3,000 now: hxxp://immediate-vendor-pay[.]me

output.description: BEC attempt via SMS, pushing an urgent vendor payment through a dubious short link.
indicators: No official phone or internal verification method
Immediate threat of 'late fee' with a suspicious link
Generic text demanding payment outside normal channels
Likely smishing link to collect credentials or direct funds

instruction: Analyze an email from 'HumanResource@corpupdates[.]online' asking employees to sign a new direct deposit form online.

input.subject: Direct Deposit Form - Action Required
input.body: Sign the attached e-form with your bank info to ensure no payroll interruption. Act now!

output.description: Phishing email impersonating HR, prompting employees to fill in direct deposit details via an attached e-form.

Unverified e-form for bank info collection
Pressure to avoid 'payroll interruption'
Attempts to capture sensitive financial data

instruction: Determine if this phone call from 'CFO’s assistant' about a last-minute invoice settlement before quarter’s end is real or suspicious.

input.scenario: They say the CFO is traveling, wants an urgent wire transfer done to meet end-of-quarter obligations.

output.description: Impersonation of CFO’s assistant pressuring immediate wire to a likely fraudulent account under quarter-end pretext.
indicators: Caller ID withheld, no means to verify identity

Common BEC scenario exploiting time sensitivity
